rsbNotes.title: Ps 72
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 72 The second part of Psalms concludes with a royal psalm asking God to bless the just king. Some of the language goes beyond what applies to the earthly king, anticipating the Messiah.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:title
rsbNotes.text: 72:title See Introduction: Author. The Septuagint (ancient Greek translation of the Old Testament) understands the title to name Solomon as the subject matter and not as the author of the psalm. The traditional understanding of the Hebrew is to indicate authorship.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:1
rsbNotes.text: 72:1 your justice . . . your righteousness. God, the divine King, is the source of all justice and righteousness. If the human king is to have such qualities, he must receive them from God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:2
rsbNotes.text: 72:2 your people. The human king receives his calling from the divine King.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:3
rsbNotes.text: 72:3 prosperity. See note 122:6.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:4
rsbNotes.text: 72:4 poor . . . needy. The king had a special responsibility to the vulnerable in society. God has a special concern and love for the poor, and the earthly king must take special care of them. See 9:18 note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:5
rsbNotes.text: 72:5 while the sun endures. As applied to an earthly king, this is a poetic overstatement. The language looks forward to the one King who will live forever (Luke 1:33; Heb. 7:16; Rev. 11:15).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:8
rsbNotes.text: 72:8 from sea to sea. There is an allusion here to the promised boundaries of Ex. 23:31, but the language far exceeds any achievement of an earthly king of Israel, and so looks forward to the Messiah’s reign.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:9
rsbNotes.text: 72:9 desert tribes. He will subdue the rebellious tribes of the desert.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:10
rsbNotes.text: 72:10 Tarshish . . . Sheba . . . Seba. These places were considered to be remote. Tarshish is usually associated with Tartessus in Spain. Sheba and probably Seba are in southern Arabia.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:17
rsbNotes.text: 72:17 May his name endure forever. The verse recalls the Abrahamic promises of Gen. 12:2, 3. The king is a focal point for the society of God’s people. He represents the people and is the heir of the promises; in Jesus Christ these promises come to fulfillment.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:18–19
rsbNotes.text: 72:18, 19 Each of the five books of the Psalms concludes with a doxology praising the name of the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 72:20
rsbNotes.text: 72:20 At some point in the process of collecting the psalms, all of the psalms of David were grouped together in the first two books. This unity was not preserved as the book continued, and this verse cannot be applied strictly to Ps. 1–72.
